heisig_chinese_memo: If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.
heisig_story: The character for stop is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot.
koohiiStory1: If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe itÂ´s some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.
koohiiStory2: If you donÂ´t remember this one from the 10,000,000 STOP signs on roads all over Japan, youÂ´re beyyond help!

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The stop radical is the same as the stop kanji.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You have to stop because there is a sheep (ã—) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine the fluffy wool of the sheep, stopping you from moving forward. You can't push past it, no matter how hard you try.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.
origin_of_ch_char_book: How did the Chinese refer to people who have passed away, the ancestors, in other words? They drew it like this: (å…ˆ, xian=hsien, earlier, elder generation). The top part (æ­¢, zhi=chih, stop) is the footprint going forth over a base line , and the bottom part (äºº, ren, human) means a person. That is, someone following the footsteps of the person who went before him/her.,(ç¶“, ç», jing, pass; channel) There is a thread on the left. On the right, there are many strands of the thread hanging on the tree , and there is a big loom underneath for weaving. When threads are woven together, then it becomes a fabric. It is now used to mean a â€˜passâ€™, or â€˜economyâ€™. (å¸ƒ, bu, cloth) A hand takes a long tool, and the fabric is rolled up. Someone is flattening a piece of cloth with a bat. It is used as the meaning of â€˜fabricâ€™ and â€˜flattenâ€™. (å¸‚, shi, city; market) This character meant â€˜to stopâ€™ æ­¢ (zhi=chih, stop). Below is the roll of cloth, for making clothes. Textiles were an important trading item. This cloth is sold in specific locations, at a â€˜marketâ€™ or in a â€˜cityâ€™. Looking at the character (è¡£, yi, clothing) which means a garment, we can easily discern two sleeves on both sides. One side of the collar is folded over the other. This character is applied in other characters. For example, (ä¾, yi, to depend on) is a combination of a garment (è¡£, yi) and a person who is wearing the garment. He needs to protect himself from the wind, sun, and cold with clothes. Clothes were precious and people treasured their clothes. Therefore, the symbol evolved to â€œto depend onâ€.,Since vaccines were not discovered yet, there were many dogs with rabies. The English expression â€œrabid dogâ€ had a strong meaning back in those times. Dogs that had rabies went mad and bit people and showed ferocity. People had to be very careful not to be bitten by mad dogs. The character (ç‹‚, kuang, mad) describes this kind of situation. The left part of this character means a foot (æ­¢, zhi=chih, stop) on a high mound (åœŸ, tu, soil). On the right, there is a dog. In other words, it depicts someone stopped on a high place and a dog beneath it barking ferociously.
humanum_full_description_en:
The Oracle and Bronze inscriptions of " Zhi " are all single-body pictographs, like the soles of human feet. The word " zhi " in common use today is the result of the Libian change. In the ancient text of Li - before, the de soles " only " fact about the points, but also down the up do not, so the real may include " stop ", " ğ£¥‚ ", " additional information ", "ã„" four basic The form, the left foot pointing upward or forward, the right foot upward or forward, the left foot downward or backward, and the right foot downward or backward, are also deformed. Through a mixture of the four, many space-oriented word form, such as " step ", " Jiang ", " Zhi ", " down ", " Wei ", " contradictory ", " out ", " each ", etc. .

It is only the first text of " toe ", but it refers to the entire sole of the foot, and can even refer to a moving human body in general. " Zhi " is one of the most important components of Chinese characters, and was later phoned as the " stop " for stopping or restraining. In addition, the interpretation of the word " zhi " in the "Shuowen" reads : "Zhi, Xia Jiye. There is a place like a tree, so it is enough to stop. All that belongs to stop is to stop." This explanation probably only explains " stop "" is used as the extended meaning of " site " or "xiaji", not the original meaning of " zhe " which is " stop ".

The word " stop " oracle bone inscriptions is used as the original meaning, such as "He Ji" 13688: "Shi Zhi", meaning that the feet have disease. " Zhi " can also be used as the name of the country and person. In addition, " Zhi " is also known as " Zhi ", which is used as a sacrifice name, such as "He Ji" 23408: "Zhi (Zhi) Day."

The inscription " stop " is used as a person's name. Five-year Yan Shenggui (formerly known as Five-Year Zhao Bohu): "Yu Lao, only public servants (yong) Tutian are many ğ§§’." Refers to my old age, and the number of people owned by Zhi Gong has been subjected to justice many times. Investigation (Lin Yuan).
humanum_short_description_en: The word " stop " in the oracle bone inscriptions and bronze inscriptions resembles the shape of " foot ", which refers to the soles of human feet. " Stop " is an important part of Chinese characters. Borrowed later to indicate stop.

origin_of_ch_char_book: How did the Chinese refer to people who have passed away, the ancestors, in other words? They drew it like this: (å…ˆ, xian=hsien, earlier, elder generation). The top part (æ­¢, zhi=chih, stop) is the footprint going forth over a base line , and the bottom part (äºº, ren, human) means a person. That is, someone following the footsteps of the person who went before him/her.,(ç¶“, ç», jing, pass; channel) There is a thread on the left. On the right, there are many strands of the thread hanging on the tree , and there is a big loom underneath for weaving. When threads are woven together, then it becomes a fabric. It is now used to mean a â€˜passâ€™, or â€˜economyâ€™. (å¸ƒ, bu, cloth) A hand takes a long tool, and the fabric is rolled up. Someone is flattening a piece of cloth with a bat. It is used as the meaning of â€˜fabricâ€™ and â€˜flattenâ€™. (å¸‚, shi, city; market) This character meant â€˜to stopâ€™ æ­¢ (zhi=chih, stop). Below is the roll of cloth, for making clothes. Textiles were an important trading item. This cloth is sold in specific locations, at a â€˜marketâ€™ or in a â€˜cityâ€™. Looking at the character (è¡£, yi, clothing) which means a garment, we can easily discern two sleeves on both sides. One side of the collar is folded over the other. This character is applied in other characters. For example, (ä¾, yi, to depend on) is a combination of a garment (è¡£, yi) and a person who is wearing the garment. He needs to protect himself from the wind, sun, and cold with clothes. Clothes were precious and people treasured their clothes. Therefore, the symbol evolved to â€œto depend onâ€.,Since vaccines were not discovered yet, there were many dogs with rabies. The English expression â€œrabid dogâ€ had a strong meaning back in those times. Dogs that had rabies went mad and bit people and showed ferocity. People had to be very careful not to be bitten by mad dogs. The character (ç‹‚, kuang, mad) describes this kind of situation. The left part of this character means a foot (æ­¢, zhi=chih, stop) on a high mound (åœŸ, tu, soil). On the right, there is a dog. In other words, it depicts someone stopped on a high place and a dog beneath it barking ferociously.

Heisig constituents: stop, footprint
Heisig: The character for stop is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot.
* Although the meaning of stop will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of footprint.

The Oracle and Bronze inscriptions of " Zhi" are all single-body pictographs, like the soles of human feet. The word " zhi" in common use today is the result of the Libian change. In the ancient text of Li - before, the de soles " only" fact about the points, but also down the up do not, so the real may include " stop", " ğ£¥‚", " additional information", " ã„" four basic The form, the left foot pointing upward or forward, the right foot upward or forward, the left foot downward or backward, and the right foot downward or backward, are also deformed. Through a mixture of the four, many space-oriented word form, such as " step", " Jiang", " Zhi", " down", " Wei", " contradictory", " out", " each", etc. . It is only the first text of " toe", but it refers to the entire sole of the foot, and can even refer to a moving human body in general. " Zhi" is one of the most important components of Chinese characters, and was later phoned as the " stop" for stopping or restraining. In addition, the interpretation of the word " zhi" in the "Shuowen" reads : "Zhi, Xia Jiye. There is a place like a tree, so it is enough to stop. All that belongs to stop is to stop." This explanation probably only explains " stop"" is used as the extended meaning of " site" or "xiaji", not the original meaning of " zhe" which is " stop". The word " stop" oracle bone inscriptions is used as the original meaning, such as "He Ji" 13688: "Shi Zhi", meaning that the feet have disease. " Zhi" can also be used as the name of the country and person. In addition, " Zhi" is also known as " Zhi", which is used as a sacrifice name, such as "He Ji" 23408: "Zhi (Zhi) Day."
